Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Psycholinguistic and Neurocognitive Indices of Prediction in Processing Nonliteral and Fixed Expressions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
In its most successful form, language connects people. Through communication, people of different backgrounds are able to share ideas and experiences and ultimately bridge gaps across cultures. A challenge presents itself, however, when communication is not successful and the inability to understand language creates a barrier. Idioms are an excellent example of an environment where misinterpretations can arise. For the average literate adult speaker, a highly familiar idiom, such as "a slap in the face" or "kick the bucket," is one where, once a particular ordering of words is recognized and the surrounding context is informative enough, the nonliteral meaning becomes most probable, and the nonliteral meaning can easily be retrieved. As these expressions communicate more than what is explicitly said, they are often difficult for second-language speakers to master. Further, as many idioms also have a plausible literal interpretation, it can be rather ambiguous for a learner to determine whether the literal interpretation was meant, or whether a nonliteral meaning was intended (e.g. "The man kicked the bucket that was full of water"). While native speakers benefit from their daily exposure to these expressions in conversational speech, second-language learners are disadvantaged due to their lack of exposure, and often interpret idiomatic language literally, or attempt to translate and use idioms from their native language.

Under the direction of Drs. Darren Tanner and Kiel Christianson, Nyssa Bulkes will conduct doctoral dissertation research with two primary goals: 1) to identify in closer detail how idioms are processed in real-time during reading, and 2) to understand how second-language learners process formulaic, fixed expressions. This research compares idiomatic expressions to literal collocations (e.g. "watch a movie" or "walk the dog"), both of which are familiar types of language to native speakers, due to their frequent co-occurrence. While more experience with the language facilitates recognition of these types of expressions in native speakers, no research to date has compared how these expressions are read during sentence processing, and whether one type of "chunk-like" expression is processed by the brain any differently. The current project will use measures of eye movements and real-time neural activity during native and nonnative reading in an effort to better compare how these populations process literal and nonliteral language. Specifically, understanding how highly familiar idiomatic expressions (e.g. idioms, "kick the bucket") compare to highly familiar literal expressions (e.g. collocations, "watch a movie") has the potential to illustrate how idiomatic, nonliteral expressions are represented in the minds of native speakers. Additionally, understanding how second-language learners process these different types of fixed expressions during natural reading has the potential to help to inform second-language instruction. By tying language comprehension processes to the cognitive and neural mechanisms supporting them, we are afforded a deeper understanding of what information second-language learners make use of as they comprehend language in real time. This understanding will ultimately better support the formulation of effective teaching interventions, working to promote fluency and successful acquisition in second-language classrooms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As fluent users of language, we, as humans, know what works. We know when to use conventional expressions (i.e. “How are you?”) and when not to, and further, we know how to respond to those conventionalities in contextually appropriate ways. Mastery of conventional expressions, or collocations—both their acquisition and their use—is a key component of native-like language processing. For example, the use of conventional expressions helps us communicate quickly and seemingly effortlessly. By using pre-constructed forms, like conventional expressions, we free up processing resources for other tasks and, simultaneously, we ensure that our communicative message will be correctly and easily received. Within the family of conventional expressions are idioms (i.e. “a slap in the face”) and literal collocations (i.e. “wash your hands”), both types of language that we know usually “go-together”. With this project, we set out to better understand how the meanings of the parts of these expressions (i.e. “slap” in “a slap on the wrist”) contribute to the comprehension of the whole. Further, when controlling for variables we know affect language comprehension (i.e. word frequency, length in characters), we wanted to know if we represent semantically opaque expressions (i.e. idioms) any differently from semantically transparent (i.e. literal collocations) expressions. By investigating this, we wanted to help answer the broader question of what types of language we represent in the brain—only parts, or do we represent longer expressions, too—and how this differs when the brain in question is nonnative, as in the case of second-language learners. By examining this in both first- and second-language comprehension, we are better able to provide a nuanced picture of how conventional expressions are represented in our brains and, further, what it takes to retrieve their meaning.

Under the direction of Drs. Darren Tanner and Kiel Christianson, Nyssa Bulkes completed this research, and used it to write and successfully defend her dissertation. The primary questions of this project were: 1) to identify in closer detail how conventional expressions (i.e. idioms, literal collocations) are processed in real-time during reading, and 2) to understand how second-language learners process language containing conventional expressions. To answer these questions, we conducted two sets of experiments. In studies where we recorded participants’ eye movements during natural reading, results showed few differences comparing reading idioms and reading literal collocations in a first language. Only in cases where the reading context was more challenging (i.e. where the words had misspellings) were idioms harder for native readers. Proficient nonnative speakers also took longer to read idioms. In both cases, the difficulty was apparent in later measures, which index challenges in integrative processing, not word identification or lexical access. This suggests that while idioms and literal collocations do not differ in terms of processing cost when they appear as expected, when they occur in less-than-ideal environments, this underscores the additional processing required of idioms, namely the resources needed to process the meaning above the sentence level. Further, in studies where we recorded how long it took participants to decide whether strings of English words were meaningful expressions or not, native speakers were faster to respond to idioms than they were to respond to literal collocations. These results support a dual-route model of language processing, specifically where the context (i.e. natural reading versus experiencing phrases in isolation) determines whether idioms are processed either incrementally, like literal language, or holistically, like long words. Finally, to additionally tease apart how reading environment impacts the ability to predict what’s upcoming in a sentence, we recorded participants’ as they read stimuli containing words spelled correctly or incorrectly. When participants were able to read more naturally—rather than reading at a fixed rate determined by us—we found that they were more sensitive to unexpected spellings during early stages of word recognition. Results confirm the findings from the eye movement data, where in cases where people are allowed to read more naturally, their sensitivity to the linguistic content increases. This highlights the merit of using natural reading contexts in scientific explorations of how lower-level sensory information (i.e. spelling) interacts with higher-level linguistic information (i.e. semantics, context). Finally, the results of this dissertation support a model of language processing that is dynamic, where factors such as context—both reading environment as well as language environment—impact language comprehension in meaningful and specific ways.
